title: 106_s1508
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Indian Tribal Justice Technical and Legal Assistance Act of 2000". The Congress recognizes the government-to-government relationship with Indian tribes, their sovereignty over lands, high rates of violent crime in Indian country, and the importance of tribal justice systems for safety and political integrity. Enhancing tribal court systems and improving access to those systems supports tribal self-determination and economic self-sufficiency. Inadequate funding and coordination hinder technical and legal assistance for tribal justice systems. Tribal court membership organizations play a crucial role in providing training and assistance. Indian legal services programs, funded in part by the Legal Services Corporation, have a proven track record. The Legal Services Corporation funds Indian legal services programs that provide cost-effective legal assistance in tribal court forums, contributing to the development of tribal courts and jurisprudence. Adequate technical assistance to tribal courts and individuals is crucial for strong tribal court systems. The Legal Services Corporation funds Indian legal services programs to provide cost-effective legal assistance in tribal court forums, contributing to the development of tribal courts and jurisprudence. The Act aims to provide technical and legal assistance to Indian tribes, strengthen tribal court systems, enhance tribal governments and economies, and promote collaboration among organizations within tribal justice systems. The Act aims to provide legal assistance services for Indian tribes, members, and tribal justice systems to develop tribal judicial systems. The Act aims to provide legal assistance services for Indian tribes, members, and tribal justice systems to develop tribal judicial systems. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "Attorney General" as the US Attorney General and "Indian lands" as including lands within Indian country or Indian reservations. The curr_chunk defines "Indian tribe" as a group eligible for special programs and services, and "judicial personnel" as officials within the tribal judicial system. The curr_chunk defines "non-profit entities" as per section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, "Office of Tribal Justice" as the Office of Tribal Justice in the United States Department of Justice, and "tribal justice system" as the entire judicial branch of an Indian tribe, including various dispute resolution methods and courts. TITLE I--TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, CIVIL AND CRIMINAL LEGAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS

SEC. 101. TRIBAL JUSTICE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS: The Attorney General, in consultation with the Office of Tribal Justice, awards grants to national or regional organizations with tribal justice system members for training and technical assistance.

SEC. 102. TRIBAL CIVIL LEGAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS: Grants are provided for civil legal assistance to tribal communities. SEC. 102. TRIBAL CIVIL LEGAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS: The Attorney General awards grants to non-profit entities providing legal assistance services for Indian tribes, members, or tribal justice systems based on Federal poverty guidelines. SEC. 103. TRIBAL CRIMINAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS: The Attorney General awards grants to non-profit entities providing criminal legal assistance to members of Indian tribes and tribal justice systems, including adult criminal actions, juvenile delinquency actions, and guardian-ad-litem appointments. Funding may also be used for other purposes consistent with the Act. SEC. 104. NO OFFSET. Federal agencies cannot offset funds provided in this Act for Indian tribal court membership organizations or legal services against other available funds for tribal justice system assistance. SEC. 105. TRIBAL AUTHORITY. SEC. 105. TRIBAL AUTHORITY. This section ensures that the Act does not infringe on tribal governments' sovereign authority to enact and enforce laws, appoint personnel, determine their legal system, maintain traditional dispute resolution forums, or imply that tribal justice systems are under the control of the United States. It also reaffirms the trust responsibility of the United States to Indian tribal governments and their justice systems. SEC. 106. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 for activities under this title. The Attorney General may award grants and provide technical assistance to Indian tribes for the development and enhancement of tribal justice systems, including tribal codes, inter-tribal courts, probation services, juvenile services, and traditional dispute resolution methods. Consultation with the Office of Tribal Justice may be conducted. The Attorney General may consult with the Office of Tribal Justice and other tribal or Federal officials. The Attorney General is authorized to create regulations and guidelines for this title. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. SEC. 202 of the Indian Tribal Justice Act is amended to update the years referenced. Section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to make various changes, including altering subsections related to eligibility criteria for selecting an allotment for veterans who served in South East Asia during a specific period. SEC. 302 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to subject a beneficiary's interest in a settlement trust to creditor action only to the extent that Settlement Common Stock is subject to such action. Additionally, TITLE IV introduces a National Leadership Symposium for American Indian, Alaskan Native, and Native Hawaiian youth. The National Leadership Symposium for American Indian, Alaskan Native, and Native Hawaiian youth will receive $2,200,000 for administration by the Secretary of Education. The symposium will focus on the traditions and values of American democracy, offering youth seminar programs in Washington, DC, in conjunction with the opening of the Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian. The goal is to enhance the participation of these youth in American government. The National Leadership Symposium aims to involve Indian, Alaskan Native, and Native Hawaiian youth in the American political process through hands-on experience with the US Government.
